message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and Estriol suggest a risk for Down syndrome or other chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. Amniocentesis is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling is an alternative but it is usually done earlier in pregnancy. Return to clinic in 4 weeks or ultrasound for nuchal translucency are not appropriate actions in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and Estriol are indicative of a potential chromosomal abnormality or neural tube defect. Amniocentesis is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of action for the pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and estriol in the quadruple screen suggest a risk of Down syndrome or another chromosomal abnormality. Amniocentesis can be used to confirm the diagnosis. The other options are not sufficient for a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormal results on the quadruple screen suggest a risk of fetal chromosomal abnormalities or neural tube defects, which can be confirmed through amniocentesis. Chorionic villus sampling is also an option but is usually done earlier in pregnancy. Return to clinic in 4 weeks or ultrasound for nuchal translucency would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low AFP, hCG, and estriol levels are suggestive of Down syndrome, with a sensitivity of up to 85%. Amniocentesis can help confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling can also be done, but it carries a higher risk of miscarriage. Waiting 4 weeks may delay necessary interventions, and an ultrasound for nuchal translucency is not as definitive as amniocentesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormal results on the quadruple screen suggest an increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities or neural tube defects. Amniocentesis would be the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling can be done earlier in pregnancy but carries a higher risk of miscarriage. Return to clinic in 4 weeks or ultrasound for nuchal translucency would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and Estriol in the quadruple screen suggest a risk for Down syndrome. Amniocentesis can confirm the diagnosis with a high degree of accuracy. Chorionic villus sampling can also be used, but it carries a slightly higher risk of miscarriage. Return to clinic in 4 weeks would delay diagnosis and treatment. Ultrasound for nuchal translucency is typically done earlier in pregnancy, around 11-14 weeks, and is not as accurate for diagnosing Down syndrome as amniocentesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and estriol suggest an increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome. Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test that can confirm the diagnosis by analyzing the fetal cells in amniotic fluid. Chorionic villus sampling is also a diagnostic test but it is usually performed earlier in pregnancy, typically around 10 to 12 weeks. Return to clinic in 4 weeks and ultrasound for nuchal translucency are not diagnostic tests and will not confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low levels of AFP, hCG, and Estriol suggest a risk for Down syndrome, Trisomy 18, or Neural tube defects. Amniocentesis is the next step to confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling can also be used but is associated with a slightly higher risk of fetal loss. Return to clinic in 4 weeks or ultrasound for nuchal translucency will not confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The results of the quadruple screen suggest an increased risk of Down syndrome or other chromosomal abnormalities. Amniocentesis is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling can also be used, but it carries a higher risk of miscarriage. Return to clinic in 4 weeks or ultrasound for nuchal translucency are not appropriate options for confirming the diagnosis.
